I've been looking up links on the anti-trust law, and it does take care of what the estate tax is about. (preventing wealth concentration) And it does it much more fairly.
 
 The anti-trust laws are essentially anti-monopoly laws. They are meant to encourage short and long-term competition. (which is good for the consumer) The idea is to stop things like price-fixing and 'tying'. (price fixing: the major players in a market get together and all raise the price, tying: a company with a monopoly on product A makes A only buyable in a package with product B) The basic theory is that once a company gets a large share of a market, they are firmly entrenched, can drive out old and new competitors with temporarily very low prices and then raise them when they are the only choice. So this law, in theory, prevents anyone from getting unfair control on a market and preventing competition.
